questions.question_text: A customer calls the help desk to report that users are unable to access any network resources. The issue started earlier in the day when an employee rearranged the wiring closet. A technician goes to the site but does not observe any obvious damage. The statistics output on the switch indicates high CPU usage, and all the lights on the switch are blinking rapidly in unison. Which of the following is the MOST likely explanation for these symptoms?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
The symptoms, including high CPU usage and rapidly blinking switch lights, are most likely due to a cable loop in the network causing a broadcast storm, which is overwhelming network resources and disrupting connectivity.

Selected Answer: C
C. A cable was looped and created a broadcast storm.

The symptoms described, including high CPU usage on the switch, rapidly blinking lights, and users being unable to access network resources, are indicative of a broadcast storm. A broadcast storm occurs when there is a loop in the network, causing broadcast traffic to circulate endlessly and overwhelm the network.

choices.D: A Cat 6 cable from the modem to the router was replaced with Cat 5e.
choices.B: The line between the switch and the upstream router was removed.
choices.C: A cable was looped and created a broadcast storm.
choices.A: The switch was rebooted and set to run in safe mode.

discussion.content: Its not even 255 its 225

The subnet mask is incorrect. It only gives you 32 IP address which only 30 are useable. Check out this guys videos on subnetting, easiest method I have ever seen: https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLp8wxQDS4nSp2urgEIqmrJyf5Wc1vInGg&si=uYG1290cfEQZixT6

comments.content: Thank you! I've looked at many videos about subnetting but this was by far the easiest to understand!

discussion.content: its the subnet mask, look closely at the host bits....225.225.225

255.255.255.224 would be a /27.

The problem is that a /27 creates 8 subnets of 32 hosts. (30 usable host if you exclude the network and broadcast addresses of each subnet)

The Gateway address is 192.168.1.1 which falls into the first subnet of (192.168.1.0 - 192.168.1.31) range, while the PC has the ip address of 192.168.1.55 which falls into the second subnet range of (192.168.1.32 - 192.168.1.63)

The PC is in a different subnet than the gateway.

comments.content: are you guys believing they made a mistake in the subnet mast cuz everyone seems to be saying 255.255.255.224 but in the question is 225.225.225.224

It's a valid subnet mask. in CIDR notation, 255.255.255.224 would be a /27.

The problem is that a /27 creates 8 subnets of 32 hosts. (30 usable host if you exclude the network and broadcast addresses of each subnet)
Given that the Gateway address is 192.168.1.1 which falls into the first subnet of (192.168.1.0 - 192.168.1.31) range, while the PC has the ip address of 192.168.1.55 which falls into the second subnet range of (192.168.1.32 - 192.168.1.63)

The PC is in a different subnet than the gateway.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
The subnet mask "225.225.225.224" is not a valid subnet mask. Subnet masks should consist of consecutive 1s followed by consecutive 0s.
A common subnet mask for a typical home or small business network is "255.255.255.0" (or represented as "/24" in CIDR notation). The provided subnet mask is invalid and needs to be corrected.

Selected Answer: A
224 is a subnet mask of /27 which is 8 subnets of 32 IPs.

comments.content: The PC doesn't have an APIPA address. the address is 192.168.1.55
fyi the subnet in the question is 255.255.255.224 not 255.255.255.0

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
A is wrong because the subnet mask is correctly configured for the network. The subnet mask is 255.255.255.0, which means the network has 24 bits for the network ID and 8 bits for the host ID. The network address is 192.168.1.0, and the host address is 192.168.1.100. Both are valid for this subnet.

The correct answer is D, because the PC is not getting a valid IP address from the DHCP server. The PC has an APIPA address, which is in the range of 169.254.0.1 to 169.254.255.254. This indicates that the PC could not contact a DHCP server and assigned itself a link-local address. This address cannot communicate with other devices outside the local network segment. The DHCP server might be down, misconfigured, or unreachable.

Selected Answer: A
The misconfigured parameter in the provided network configuration is:

A. Subnet mask

The subnet mask should be in the standard format, such as 255.255.255.0, which is a typical subnet mask for a Class C network. The value provided (225.225.225.224) is not a valid subnet mask and should be corrected to match the appropriate subnet for the network, often 255.255.255.0 for a typical home or small office network.
Should be the DNS server, no?..

questions.question_text: A user stores large graphic files. The time required to transfer the files to the server is excessive due to network congestion. The user's budget does not allow for the current switches to be replaced. Which of the following can be used to provide FASTER transfer times?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B. Jumbo frames

Jumbo frames can be used to provide faster transfer times for large files in situations where network congestion is a concern. Jumbo frames allow for larger data payloads to be transmitted in a single frame, reducing the overhead associated with smaller frames and improving efficiency.

Option B, Jumbo frames, would help in this scenario by reducing the number of frames required to transfer large graphic files, thus improving the overall transfer speed.

Selected Answer: B
Using jumbo frames in a LAN can provide several advantages, particularly for applications that require high throughput and low latency, such as video streaming, file transfer, or backup. These benefits include improved network efficiency, reduced network congestion, and increased data throughput.

Selected Answer: B
Jumbo frames is the right answer

LACP is the answer.
Because network congestion can be mitigated by using LACP

comments.content: LACP won't help with the congestion; Jumbo frames will

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
NG firewall does multifunction

A next-generation firewall is a part of the third generation of firewall technology, combining a traditional firewall with other network device filtering functions, such as an application firewall using in-line deep packet inspection, an intrusion prevention system. Wikipedia
"and manage multiple IPSec site-to-site connections" << That did not make a lot of sense to me

Selected Answer: C
C. Next-generation firewall
Next-generation Firewall

questions.question_text: Which of the following types of devices can provide content filtering and threat protection, and manage multiple IPSec site-to-site connections?

A sales team at a company uses a SaaS solution primarily for videoconferencing and a CRM application that connects to a database server in the corporate data center. Which of the following VPN solutions would allow secure, remote access for sales staff to the CRM application without impacting videoconferencing traffic?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
The best VPN solution for the sales team would be a split tunneling VPN. This type of VPN allows you to route specific traffic through the VPN tunnel, while sending other traffic directly over the internet.

In this case, the sales team would route the CRM traffic through the VPN tunnel to ensure that it is secure. However, they would not route the videoconferencing traffic through the VPN tunnel, as this could impact the performance of their video calls.

Here are some of the benefits of using a split tunneling VPN:

Security: Split tunneling VPNs can help to improve the security of your network by routing sensitive traffic through the VPN tunnel.
Performance: Split tunneling VPNs can help to improve the performance of your network by sending non-sensitive traffic directly over the internet.
Flexibility: Split tunneling VPNs give you more flexibility in how you route your traffic.
